turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Did you buy all these books retail, or do you send away for like a "shrink kit" that comes with all these volumes included?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Have you read all these books, Will?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Probably not.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: How about the ones on that shelf?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yeah, I read those.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: What did you think?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'm not here for a fuckin' book report. They're your books, why don't you read 'em?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I did.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: That must have taken you a long time.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Yeah, it did take me a long time.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: "A History of the United States, Volume I." If you want to read a real history book, read Howard Zinn's "A People's History of the United States." That book will knock you on your ass.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: How about Noam Chomsky's "Manufacturing Consent?"

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You people baffle me. You spend all this money on beautiful, fancy books-- and they're the wrong fuckin' books.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: You think so?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Whatever blows your hair back.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Guy your age shouldn't smoke so much. Stunt your growth.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You're right. It really gets in the way of my jazzercizing.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Yes, I do.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Nautilus?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Free weights. WILL Oh yeah? Me too. What do you bench?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Yeah. Do you paint?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Crayons?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: This is a real piece of shit.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Tell me what you really think.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Poor color composition, lousy use of space. But that shit doesn't really concern me.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: What does?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: The color here, see how dark it is? It's interesting.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: What is?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I think you're one step away from cutting your ear off.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Oh, "Starry Night" time, huh?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You ever heard the saying, "any port in a storm?"

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Sure, how 'bout "still waters run deep"--

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: --Well, maybe that means you.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Maybe what mea--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Maybe you should be a patient and sit down.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Maybe you married the wrong woman.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Watch your mouth.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: That's it isn't it? You married the wrong woman. She leave you? Was she bangin' someone else?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: If you ever disrespect my wife again...I will end you.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Time's up.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: So what's with this place? You have a swan fetish? Is this something you'd like to talk about?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I was thinking about what you said to me the other day, about my painting. I stayed up half the night thinking about it and then something occured to me and I fell into a deep peaceful sleep and haven't thought about you since. You know what occurred to me?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: You're just a boy. You don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Why thank you.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: You've never been out of Boston.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: So if I asked you about art you could give me the skinny on every art book ever written...Michelangelo? You know a lot about him I bet. Life's work, criticisms, political aspirations. But you couldn't tell me what it smells like in the Sistine Chapel. You've never stood there and looked up at that beautiful ceiling. And if I asked you about women I'm sure you could give me a syllabus of your personal favorites, and maybe you've been laid a few times too. But you couldn't tell me how it feels to wake up next to a woman and be truly happy. If I asked you about war you could refer me to a bevy of fictional and non-fictional material, but you've never been in one. You've never held your best friend's head in your lap and watched him draw his last breath, looking to you for help. And if I asked you about love I'd get a sonnet, but you've never looked at a woman and been truly vulnerable. Known that someone could kill you with a look. That someone could rescue you from grief. That God had put an angel on Earth just for you. And you wouldn't know how it felt to be her angel. To have the love be there for her forever. Through anything, through cancer. You wouldn't know about sleeping sitting up in a hospital room for two months holding her hand and not leaving because the doctors could see in your eyes that the term "visiting hours" didn't apply to you. And you wouldn't know about real loss, because that only occurs when you lose something you love more than yourself, and you've never dared to love anything that much. I look at you and I don't see an intelligent confident man, I don't see a peer, and I don't see my equal. I see a boy. Nobody could possibly understand you, right Will? Yet you presume to know so much about me because of a painting you saw. You must know everything about me. You're an orphan, right?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You know, I was on this plane once. And I'm sittin' there and the captain comes on and is like "we'll be cruising at 35,000 feet," and does his thing, then he puts the mike down but forgets to turn it off. Then he says "man, all I want right now is a blow-job and a cup of coffee." So the stewardess goes runnin' up towards the cock-pit to tell him the mike's still on, and this guy in the back of the plane goes "don't forget the coffee!"

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: You've never been on a plane.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I know, but the joke's better if I tell it in the first person.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Yeah? You got a lady now?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yeah, I went on a date last week.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: How'd it go?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Well, are you going out again?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Haven't called her.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Jesus Christ, you are an amateur.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I know what I'm doing. She's different from the other girls I met. We have a really good time. She's smart, beautiful, fun...

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: So Christ, call her up.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Why? So I can realize she's not so smart. That she's boring. You don't get it. Right now she's perfect, I don't want to ruin that.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: And right now you're perfect too. Maybe you don't want to ruin that.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I teach this shit, I didn't say I knew how to do it.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You ever think about gettin' remarried?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: My wife's dead.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Hence, the word remarried.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: My wife's dead.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Well I think that's a wonderful philosophy, Sean. That way you can go through the rest of your life without having to really know anyone.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Really? How'd the date go? WILL Do you still counsel veterans?  I read your book last night.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: No, I don't.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I gave that up when my wife got sick.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Is that why you didn't write anything else?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I didn't write anything else 'cause nobody, including most of my colleagues bothered to read the first one.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Well, I've read you colleagues. Your book was good, Sean.  All those guys were in your platoon?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What happened to that guy from Kentucky?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Lon? He got married. He has a kid. I kind of lost touch with him after Nancy got sick.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Do you ever wonder what your life would be like if you never met your wife?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: What? Do I wonder if I'd be better off if I never met my wife?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You don't regret meetin' your wife?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Why? Because of the pain I feel now? I have regrets Will, but I don't regret a singel day I spent with her.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: When did you know she was the one?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: October 21, 1975. Game six of the World Series. Biggest game in Red Sox history, Me and my friends slept out on the sidewalk all night to get tickets. We were sitting in a bar waiting for the game to start and in walks this girl. What a game that was. Tie game in the bottom of the tenth inning, in steps Carlton Fisk, hit a long fly ball down the left field line. Thirty-five thousand fans on their feet, screamin' at the ball to stay fair. Fisk is runnin' up the baseline, wavin' at the ball like a madman. It hits the foul pole, home run. Thirty-five thousand people went crazy. And I wasn't one of them.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Where were you?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I was havin' a drink with my future wife.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You missed Pudge Fisk's homerun to have a drink with a woman you had never met?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: So wait a minute. The Red Sox haven't won a World Series since nineteen eighteen, you slept out for tickets, games gonna start in twenty minutes, in walks a girl you never seen before, and you give your ticket away?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: You should have seen this girl. She lit up the room.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I don't care if Helen of Troy walked into that bar! That's game six of the World Series!

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I just slid my ticket across the table and said "sorry fellas, I gotta go see about a girl."

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: "I gotta go see about a girl"? What did they say?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: They could see that I meant it.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You're kiddin' me.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: No Will, I'm not kiddin' you. If I had gone to see that game I'd be in here talkin' abouta girl I saw at a bar twenty years ago. And how I always regretted not goin' over there and talkin' to her. I don't regret the eighteen years we were married. I don't regret givin' up couseling for six years when she got sick. I don't regret being by her side for the last two years when things got real bad. And I sure as Hell don't regret missing that damn game.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Would have been nice to catch that game though.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Well hell, I didn't know Pudge was gonna hit the home run.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: So you might be working for Uncle Sam.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Gerry says the meeting went well.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: What did you think?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What did I think?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Do you think you're alone?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Do you have a soul-mate?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Define that.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Someone who challenges you in every way. Who takes you places, opens things up for you. A soul-mate.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: They're all dead.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Not to me, they're not.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: But you can't give back to them, Will.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Not without a heater and some serious smelling salts, no...

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: That's what I'm saying, Will. You'll never have that kind of relationship in a world where you're afraid to take the first step because all you're seeing are the negative things that might happen ten miles down the road.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, what? You're going to take the professor's side on this?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Don't give me you line of shit.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I didn't want the job.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: It's not about that job. I'm not saying you should work for the government. But, you could do anything you want. And there are people who work their whole lives layin' brick so their kids have a chance at the kind of opportunity you have. What do you want to do?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I didn't ask for this.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Nobody gets what they ask for, Will. That's a cop-out.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Why is it a cop-out? I don't see anythin' wrong with layin' brick, that's somebody's home I'm buildin'. Or fixin' somebody's car, somebody's gonna get to work the next day 'cause of me. There's honor in that.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: You're right, Will. Any man who takes a forty minute train ride so those college kids can come in in the morning and their floors will be clean and their trash cans will be empty is an honorable man.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: If you won't answer my questions, you're wasting my time.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I been there. I played my hand.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: That's right. And you fuckin' lost! And some people would have the sack to lose a big hand like that and still come back and ante up again!

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Look at me. What do you want to do?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Well, I'm here.  So, is that my problem? I'm afraid of being abandoned? That was easy.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Look, a lot of that stuff goes back a long way.  And it's between me and him and it has nothing to do with you.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Do you want to talk about it?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Oh, this is your file. I have to send it back to the Judge with my evaluation.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You're not going to fail me are you?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: You want to read it?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No.  Have you had any experience with that?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Twenty years of counselling you see a lot of--

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: --No, have you had any experience with that?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It sure ain't good.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Gotta go with the belt there...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I used to go with the wrench.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: The wrench, why?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Cause fuck him, that's why.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, I know.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: It's not your fault.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: It's not your fault.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: It's not your fault.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: It's not your fault.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Don't fuck with me.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: It's not your fault.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: It's not...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I know, I know...

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Which one did you take, Will?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Over at Tri-tech. One of the jobs Professor Lambeau set me up with. I haven't told him yet, but I talked to my new boss over there and he seemed like a nice guy.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: That's what you want?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yeah, I think so.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Good for you. Congratulations.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Thanks you.  So, that's it? We're done?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: We're done. You did your time. You're a free man.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I just want you to know, Sean...

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: You're Welcome, Will.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'll keep in touch.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I'm gonna travel a little bit, so I don't know where I'll be.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: No. Thank you.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Does this violate the patient/doctor relationship?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Only if you grab my ass.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: See ya.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Good luck.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: You suck.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I've been sitting over there for forty- five minutes waiting for you to come talk to me. But I'm just tired now and I have to go home and I wasn't going to keep sitting there waiting for you.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'm Will.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Skylar. And by the way. That guy over there is a real dick and I just wanted you to know he didn't come with us.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I kind of got that impression.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Well, look, I have to go. Gotta' get up early and waste some more money on my overpriced education.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I didn't mean you. Listen, maybe...

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Here's my number.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Great, or maybe we could go somewhere and just eat a bunch of caramels.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: When you think about it, it's just as arbitrary as drinking coffee.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Okay, sounds good.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Five minutes.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I was trying to be smooth.  But at twelve-fifteen I was gonna come over there and talk to you.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: See, it's my life story. Five more minutes and I would have got to hear your best pick-up line.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: The caramel thing is my pick-up line.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It's Will, the really funny good looking guy you met at the bar?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I'm sorry, I don't recall meeting anyone who fits that description.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Okay, you got me. It's the ugly, obnoxious, toothless loser who got drunk and wouldn't leave you alone all night.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Oh Will! I was wondering when you'd call.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yeah, I figured maybe sometime this week we could go to a cafe and have some caramels.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Sounds good, where are you now?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You aren't, by any chance, Pre-law? Are you?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I don't know, it was just kind of the boring suburban thing. Private school, Harvard, and now Med. School.  I actually figured out that at the end of it, my brain will be worth a quarter of a million dollars. I shouldn't have told you that...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I bet your parents were happy to pay.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I was happy to pay. I inherited the money.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Is Harvard gettin' all that money?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Stanford. I'm leaving in June after I graduate.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: So you just want to use me and go?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Well, I'm gonna experiment on you for my anatomy class, then go.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: In that case, fine.  Want to see my magic trick?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Now, I'm gonna make all these caramels disappear.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Okay...

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Have you ever seen Annie Hall?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Well, there's this part of the movie that's about how there's always this tension on a first date where both people are thinking about what's going to happen with the whole 'good night kiss' thing.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I really don't 'date' that much.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: You know what I mean. I know you've at least thought about it.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No I haven't...

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Yes you have. You were thinking you were gonna get a good night kiss.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No I wasn't...

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Yes you were.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I was kinda' hopin' to get a "good night laid" but...I'll take a kiss.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Oh, you will?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No...I was hoping to get a kiss.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Then why don't we just get it out of the way.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Free?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Hey, I spent all my money on those caramels.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: You grew up around here?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Not far from here, South Boston.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: How was that?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Pretty boring, I guess.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I bet you have a great family.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You know, nothing special.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: You have a lot of brothers and sisters?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Do I have a lot of brothers and sisters?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Well, Irish Catholic. What do you think?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: How many?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You wouldn't believe me if I told you.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: What, five?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I have twelve big brothers.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Not a chance.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yup, you're lookin' at lucky thirteen.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Bullshit.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I swear to God.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Your house must have been a zoo.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It was great. There was always someone to play with, give you advice.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Do you know all their names?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: 'Course I do, they're my brothers.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Marky, Ricky, Danny, Terry, Mikey, Davey, Timmy, Tommy, Joey, Robby, Johnny, and Brian.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Do you keep in touch with them?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: All the time. We all live in Southie. I live with three of them now.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I want to meet them.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: We'll do that.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Where have you been?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'm sorry, I been real busy.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: You were busy? You know, I really was waiting for you to call me.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Sorry. I'm sorry. Give me another crack at it. Let me take you out.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: You should have called. I have an "O- chem" lab due tomorrow and it's impossible.  It's not an excuse dummy. I want to go out with you. But look:

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Promise?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: If you bring the caramels.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I couldn't wait till tomorrow.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: How the hell did you do that?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Didn't your mother ever tell you not to look a gift horse n the mouth?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I'm supposed to understand this.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You're not going into surgery tomorrow are you?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Then let's go have some fun.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Why do we always stay here?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: 'Cause it's nicer than my place.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I've never seen your place.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: What about your friends? Or your brothers? When do I get to meet them?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: They don't come over here that much.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I think I can make it to South Boston.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Aah, it's kind of a hike.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Is it me you're hiding from them or the other way around?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: All right, all right. We'll go.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Sometime. I don't know. Next week.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: What if I said I wouldn't sleep with you again until you let me meet your friends?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'd say...  It's only four in the mornin', they're prob'ly up.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: You men are shameful. If you're not thinking of your weiner then you're acting on its behalf.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Then on behalf of my weiner, I'd like to ask for an advance.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I thought you said you'd show me your place.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Not tonight.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: How's it goin'?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Want me to take a look?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: C'mon, give me a peek and we'll go to the battin' cages.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: It's important that I learn this.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Why is it important to you? If I inherited all that money, the only thing important to me would be workin' on my swing.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Clearly.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You're rich. What do you have to worry about?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Rich? I have an inheritance. It's two handred and fifty thousand dollars. That's exactly what it'll cost me, minus about five hundred bucks, to go all the way through med school. This is what I'm doing with that money. I could have done anything I wanted. I could have expanded my wardrobe, substantially.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Instead you're going to bust your ass for five years so you can be broke? SKYLAR No, so I can be a doctor.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: All right, Mr. Nosey Parker. Let me ask you a question? Do you have a photographic memory?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I guess. I don't know. How do you remember your phone number?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Have you ever studied Organic Chemistry?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Some, a little.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Just for fun?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I guess so.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Nobody does organic chemistry for "fun." It's unnecessary. Especially for someone like you.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Like me?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Yeah. Someone like you who divides his time, fairly evenly, between the batting cages and bars.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Do you play the piano?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Come one Will. I just want to know.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'm trying to explain it to you. So you play the piano. When you look at the keys, you see music, you see Mozart.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I see "Hot Cross Buns," but okay.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Well all right, Beethoven. He looked at a piano and saw music. The fuckin' guy was deaf when he composed the Ode to Joy. They had to turn him around to take a bow because he couldn't hear the crowd going crazy behind him. Stone deaf. He saw all of that music in his head.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: So, do you play the piano?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Not a lick. I look at a piano and I see black and white keys, three pedals and a box of wood. Beethoven, Mozart, they looked at it and it just made sense to them. They saw a piano and they could play. I couldn't paint you a picture, I probably can't hit the ball out of Fenway Park and I can't play the piano--

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: --But you can do my O-chem lab in under an hour, you can--

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: --When it came to stuff like that I could always just play.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Will? Are you awake?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Come with me to California.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I want you to come with me.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: How do you know that?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I know. I just do.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yeah, but how do you know?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I don't know. I just feel it.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: And you're sure about that?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Yeah, I'm sure.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: 'Cause that's a serious thing you're sayin'. I mean, we might be in California next week and you could find out somethin' about me that you don't like. And you might feel like "hey this is a big mistake."  But you can't take it back, 'cause you know it's real serious and you can't take somethin' like that back. Now I'm in California, 'cause you asked me to come. But you don't really want me there. And I'm stuck in California with someone who really doesn't want me there and just wishes they had a take-back.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: "Take-back?" What is that? I don't want a take-back. I want you to come to California with me.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I can't go out to California.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: One, because I have a job here and two because I live here--

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Look, Will if you're not in love with me, you can say that.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'm not sayin' I'm not in love with you.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Then what are you afraid of?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What do you mean "What am I afraid of?"

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Why won't you come with me? What are you so scared of?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What am I scared of?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Well, what aren't you scared of? You live in your safe little world where nobody challenges you and you're scared shitless to do anything else--

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: --Don't tell me about my world. You're the one that's afraid. You just want to have your little fling with the guy from the other side of town and marry--

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Is that what you think--

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: --some prick from Stanford that your parents will approve of. Then you'll sit around with the rest of the upper crust kids and talk about how you went slummin' too.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I inherited that money when I was thirteen, when my father died.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: At least you have a mother.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Fuck you! You think I want this? That money's a burden to me. Every day I wake up and I wish I could give that back. I'd give everything I have back to spend one more day with my father. But that's life. And I deal with it. So don't put that shit on me. You're the one that's afraid.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What the fuck am I afraid of?!

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: You're afraid of me. You're afraid that I won't love you back. And guess what? I'm afraid too. But at least I have the balls to it give it a shot. At least I'm honest with you.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'm not honest?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: What about your twelve brothers?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, is that what this is about? You want to hear that I don't really have any brothers? That I'm a fuckin' orphan? Is that what you want to hear?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Yes, Will. I didn't even know that?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No, you don't want to hear that.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Yes, I do, Will.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You don't want to hear that I got cigarettes put out on me when I was a little kid. That this isn't surgery

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Yes I do. Did you ever think that maybe I could help you? That maybe that's the point, that we're a team?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What, you want to come in here and save me? Is that what you want to do? Do I have a sign that says "save me" on my back?

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I don't want to "save" you. I just want to be with you. I love you. I love you!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Don't bullshit me! Don't fuckin' bullshit me!

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: You know what I want to hear? I want to hear that you don't love me. If you tell me that, then I'll leave you alone. I won't ask any questions and I won't be in your life.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I just wanted to call before you left.  I'm takin' all these job interviews. So I won't just be a construction worker.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I never cared about that.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I love you, Will.  No take-backs.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Take care.

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Goodbye.

turns.speaker: FLOYD
turns.text: You doin' the hirin'?

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Well, I'm contracting the land.

turns.speaker: FLOYD
turns.text: All right, mister. I'll go. You just show your license to contrack, an' then you make out a order--where an' when an' how much you gonna pay--an' you sign it an' we'll go.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: You trying to tell me how to run my own business?

turns.speaker: FLOYD
turns.text: 'F we're workin' for you, it's our business too. An' how do we know--  --you ain't one a the guys that sent these things out?

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Listen, Smart Guy. I'll run my business my own way. I got work. If you wanta take it, okay. If not, just sit here, that's all.

turns.speaker: FLOYD
turns.text: Twicet now I've fell for that line. Maybe he needs a thousan' men. So he get's five thousan' there, an' he'll pay fifteen cents a hour. An' you guys'll have to take it 'cause you'll be hungry.  'F he wants to hire men, let him write it out an' say what he's gonna pay. Ast to see his license. He ain't allowed by law to contrack men without a license.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Joe!

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: She'll prob'ly ride like a bull calf-- but she'll ride!

turns.speaker: PA
turns.text: Reckon we better begin roustin' 'em out if we aim to get outa here by daylight. How about it, John? How you boys comin'?

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Will ya look at her!

turns.speaker: PA
turns.text: I never knowed they was anything like her!

turns.speaker: PA
turns.text: Leave him alone, Ma--Al's just billy- goatin' around--

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Sure! I was just aimin' to meet up with a couple girls I know.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Ready, Pa?

turns.speaker: PA
turns.text: Let 'er go, Gallagher!

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Twenty days work, oh boy!

turns.speaker: PA
turns.text: Be glad to get my han' on some cotton. That's the kin' a pickin' I understan'.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Go on. Get in your tent. You don't know nothin'.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: How 'bout you?

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: *Some*body got to take the blame. They just *got* to hang it on somebody, you know.  An' I ain't doin' nothin' but set around.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: But ain't no reason--

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Lissen. I don't care nothin' about you, but if you mess in this, your whole fambly li'ble to get in trouble, an' Tom get sent back to the penitentiary.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Okay. I think you're a darn fool, though.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Sure. Why not?

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Ain't you gonna look back, Ma?--give the ol' place a last look?

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: We're goin' to California, ain't we? Awright then, let's *go* to California.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: That don't sound like you, Ma. You never was like that before.

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: I never had my house pushed over before. I never had my fambly stuck out on the road. I never had to lose... ever'thing I had in life.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: I'd come back--

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: But ef you *do* whup me, I swear you better not ever go to sleep again, because the minute you go to sleep, or you're settin' down, or your back's turned, I'm gonna knock you belly-up with a bucket.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: But it ain't runnin' away, Ma. All I wanta do is go away with another fella an' look aroun' for work by ourself--

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Well, you ain't a-goin'! Ain't *nobody* else a-goin'! We *got* here an' we gonna *stay* here, together! As long as we got the fambly unbroke I ain't scared, but it's a long bitter road we got ahead of us--  --an' I'm here to tell ya ef anybody else tries to bust us up anymore I'm a-goin' cat wild with this here piece a bar-arn!

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Ready, Ma?

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: I'll get Rosasharn.

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Maybe. Maybe twenny days work, maybe *no* days work. We ain't got it till we get it.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Whatsa matter, Ma? Gettin' scared?

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: No. Ain't ever gonna be scared no more.  I was, though. For a while I thought we was beat--*good* an' beat. Looked like we didn't have nothin' in the worl' but enemies--wasn't *no*body frien'ly anymore. It made me feel bad an' scared too--like we was lost... an' nobody cared.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Watch me pass that Chevvy.

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Woman can change better'n a man. Man lives in jerks--baby born, or somebody dies, that's a jerk--gets a farm, or loses one, an' that's a jerk. With a woman it's all one flow, like a stream, little eddies, little waterfalls, but the river it goes right on. Woman looks at it like that.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Look at that ol' coffeepot steam!

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Well, you said anybody can waltz... How'm *I* doin'?

turns.speaker: BLONDE GIRL
turns.text: Don't hold me so tight.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Why, I ain't hardly touchin' you!

turns.speaker: BLONDE GIRL
turns.text: You're *ticklin' me!*

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: That comes from not holdin' you tight *enough.*

turns.speaker: BLONDE GIRL
turns.text: Now I can't breathe.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: You bust outa jail, Tom?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Naw. They paroled me.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: What a place! How'd you like to walk acrost her?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: People done it. If they could, we could.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Lots must a died, too.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, we ain't out a it yet.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Tom? You can come on. They gone.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: We got to get outa here right away. Ever'body here? Where's Uncle John?

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Maybe the road's out.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I don't know what these cops got to do with it but I don't like it.  An' these here are our own people, all of 'em. I don't like this.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Think I'll look aroun' an' see if I can't meet me a girl.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Thing's been workin' on me, what they was yellin' about. Got me all curious.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: She's hotter'n a heifer.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Fan-belt's shot.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Any gas?

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Gallon or two?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, looks like we done it this time awright!

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Looks like about a mile. Reckon she'll make it?

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: She got to make it.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: You mean that hitch-hiker? Little short fella with a pale face?

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: I guess that's what he looked like.

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: We just picked him up on the way in. He went away this mornin' when the rate dropped.

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: What'd he look like again?

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: Short fella. Pale face.

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Was he bruised up this mornin'? About the face?

turns.speaker: AL
turns.text: I didn't see nothin'.

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Okay. Go on.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Kinda pie y'got?

turns.speaker: MAE
turns.text: Banana cream, pineapple cream, chocolate cream--and apple.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Cut me off a hunk a that banana cream, and a cuppa java.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Them wasn't two-for-a-cent candy.

turns.speaker: MAE
turns.text: What's it to you?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Them was nickel apiece candy.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: So long.

turns.speaker: MAE
turns.text: Hey, wait a minute. You got change comin'.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: Want to work?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Sure, but what is this?

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: That's not your affair. Name.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Joad.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: How many men?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Four.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: Women?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Two.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: Kids?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Two.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: Can all of you work?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Why, I guess so.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: Okay. House 63. Wages 5 cents a box. No bruised fruit. Move along and go to work right away.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: House 25. Number's on the door.

turns.speaker: MIGRANT
turns.text: Okay, mister. Whatcha payin'?

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: Two and a half cents.

turns.speaker: MIGRANT
turns.text: Two an' a half! Say, mister, a man can't make his dinner on that.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: Take it or leave it. There's 200 men coming from the South that'll be glad to get it.

turns.speaker: MIGRANT
turns.text: But--but how we gonna eat?

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: Look, I didn't set the price. I'm just working here. If you want it, take it. If you don't, turn right around and beat it.

turns.speaker: MIGRANT
turns.text: Which way is House 25?

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Open up! We hear you got a riot.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: Riot? I don't see no riot. Who're you?

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Deputy sheriffs.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: Got a warrant?

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: We don't need a warrant if it's a riot.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: Well, I don't know what you gonna do about it, because I don't hear no riot an' I don't see no riot, an' what's more I don't believe they *is* no riot.  Look for yourself.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: I don't mean to be nosy, y'understand. I just got to have certain information. What's your name?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Joad. Tom Joad.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: How many of you?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: Camp site costs a dollar a week, but you can work it out, carrying garbage, keeping the camp clean--stuff like that.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: We'll work it out. What's this committee you talkin' about?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: We got five sanitary units. Each one elects a central committee man. They make the laws, an' what they say goes.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Are you aimin' to tell me that the fellas that run this camp is jus' fellas--campin' here?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: That's the way it is.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: An' you say no cops?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: No cop can come in here without a warrant.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I can't hardly believe it. Camp I was in once, they burned it out--the deputies an' some of them poolroom fellas.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: They don't get in here. Sometimes the boys patrol the fences, especially dance nights.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You got dances too?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: We got the best dances in the county every Saturday night.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Say, who runs this place?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: Government.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Why ain't they more like it?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: *You* find out, I can't.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Anything like work aroun' here?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: Can't promise you that, but there'll be a licensed agent here tomorrow mornin', if you want to talk to him.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ma's shore gonna like it here. She ain't been treated decent for a long time.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: That cut you got?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Crate fell on me.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: Better take care of it. Store manager'll give you some stuff for it in the morning. Goodnight.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Goodnight.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Say, ain't you young Tom Joad--ol' Tom's boy?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yeah. On my way home now.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Well, I do declare!  I baptized you, son.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Why, you're the preacher!

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: *Used* to be. Not no more. I lost the call.  But boy, I sure *used* to have it! I'd get an irrigation ditch so squirmin' full of repented sinners I pretty near *drowned* half of 'em!  But not no more. I lost the sperit.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Pa always said you was never cut out to be a preacher.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: I got nothin' to preach about no more--that's all. I ain't so sure o' things.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Maybe you should a got yourself a wife.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: At my meetin's I used to get the girls glory-shoutin' till they about passed out. Then, I'd go to comfort 'em--and always end up by lovin' 'em. I'd feel bad, an' pray, an' pray, but it didn't do no good. Next time, do it again. I figgered there just wasn't no hope for me.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I never let one go by me when I could catch her.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: But you wasn't a preacher. A girl was just a girl to you. But to me they was holy vessels. I was savin' their souls.  I ast myself--what *is* this call, the Holy Sperit? Maybe *that's* love. Why, I love everybody so much I'm fit to bust sometimes!  So maybe there ain't no sin an' there ain't no virtue. There's just what people do. Some things folks do is nice, and some ain't so nice. But that's as far as any man's got a right to say.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Have a little snort?

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Course I'll say grace if somebody sets out the food--  --but my heart ain't in it.  Nice drinkin' liquor.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ought to be. That's fact'ry liquor. Cost me a buck.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Been out travelin' around?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Didn't you hear? It was in the papers.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: No, I never. What?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I been in the penitentiary for four years.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Excuse me for asking.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I don't mind any more. I'd do what I done again. I killed a guy at a dance. We was drunk. He got a knife in me and I laid him out with a shovel. Knocked his head plumb to squash.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: And you ain't ashamed?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: He had a knife in me. That's why they only gave me seven years. Got out in four--parole.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Ain't you seen your folks since then?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No, but I aim to before sundown. Gettin' kind of excited about it, too. Which way you going?

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: It don't matter. Ever since I lost the sperit it looks like I just as soon go one way as the other.  I'll go your way.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Maybe Ma'll have pork for supper. I ain't had pork but four times in four years--every Christmas.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: I'll be glad to see you pa. Last time I seen him was at a baptizin', an' he had one a the bigges' doses of the Holy Sperit I ever seen. He go to jumpin' over bushes, howlin' like a dog-wolf in moon-time. Fin'ly he picks hisself out a bush big as a piana an' he let out a squawk an' took a run at that bush. Well, sir, he cleared her but he bust his leg snap in two. They was a travellin' dentist there and he set her, an' I give her a prayin' over, but they wasn't no more Holy Sperit in your pa after that.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Lissen. This wind's fixin't to *do* somepin'!

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Shore it is. It always is, this time a year.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Is it fur?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Just around that next bend.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: Your granma was a great one, too. The third time she got religion she go it so powerful she knocked down a full-growed deacon with her fist.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: That's our place.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: They're all gone--or dead.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: They never wrote you nothing?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No. They wasn't people to write.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: This used to be mine. I give it to Grampa when I went away.  You reckon they could be dead?

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: I never heard nothin' about it.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: This is Muley Graves.  You remember the preacher, don't you?

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: I ain't no preacher anymore.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: All right, you remember the *man* then.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: She's settlin'.

turns.speaker: CASY
turns.text: What you figger to do?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: It's hard to say. Stay here till mornin' an' then go on over to Uncle John's, I reckon. After that I don't know.
